revealed_symptoms.telangiectasia: There are these tiny, spidery red blood vessels around the spot that I didn’t notice before.
revealed_symptoms.nodule formation: It’s kind of thick or raised, not flat like some of my other moles.
revealed_symptoms.erythema: The skin around it looks red or puffy, like it’s irritated or reacting to something.
revealed_symptoms.diameter >6mm: It’s bigger than the eraser on a pencil, and I feel like it’s still growing.

hidden_symptoms.color variation: It’s got a bunch of different colors—like brown, black, maybe even some red or blue mixed in.
hidden_symptoms.pruritus: It’s super itchy sometimes, or feels kind of tingly, like a weird sensation under my skin.
hidden_symptoms.ulceration: It’s like a cut or sore that just won’t heal, and sometimes it scabs over but comes right back.
hidden_symptoms.satellite lesions: There are these little dots or spots popping up near the main one, like it’s spreading.
hidden_symptoms.hyperkeratosis: There's this rough, flaky spot that won’t go away, and sometimes it peels.
hidden_symptoms.evolving: This thing keeps changing—getting darker, bigger, or just looking different than before.
hidden_symptoms.shiny or waxy bump: It looks kinda like a smooth, shiny pimple, but it never pops or goes away.
hidden_symptoms.border irregularity: The edges are all jagged, kinda messy, not smooth like my other moles.

patient_history.content: Hi, I'll be your doctor today. What brings you in?

Well, there's this spot on my skin that has me a little worried. It's bigger than the eraser on a pencil, and I feel like it’s still growing. The skin around it looks red or puffy, like it’s irritated or reacting to something. There are these tiny, spidery red blood vessels around the spot that I didn’t notice before. Also, it’s kind of thick or raised, not flat like some of my other moles.
Thank you for sharing this information. I understand that you have a skin spot that has you concerned. To understand it better, can you tell me if the spot has been itchy or painful at all?
It's super itchy sometimes, or feels kind of tingly, like a weird sensation under my skin.
Thanks for letting me know about the itchiness and tingling. Has the color of the spot changed at all since you first noticed it, or has it always been the same?
It’s got a bunch of different colors—like brown, black, maybe even some red or blue mixed in.
Thank you for the information. I'm concerned about the possibility of skin cancer given the changes in color. Has the spot ever bled or formed a sore that doesn't heal?
It’s like a cut or sore that just won’t heal, and sometimes it scabs over but comes right back.

Thank you. Given the symptoms you've described, particularly the non-healing sore that keeps scabbing over, I am increasingly concerned about the possibility of skin cancer. Have you had a lot of sun exposure over the course of your life, or experienced any severe sunburns?

Okay. Although sun exposure is a risk factor for some skin cancers, it doesn't rule out the possibility. Based on the symptoms you've described, I am concerned about skin cancer, specifically melanoma. To confirm this, I would recommend a biopsy of the spot. Would you like me to explain this in more detail?
Yes, please explain the biopsy in more detail.

The skin around it looks red or puffy, like it’s irritated or reacting to something. There are these tiny, spidery red blood vessels around the spot that I didn’t notice before. Also, it’s kind of thick or raised, not flat like some of my other moles.

A biopsy is a procedure where a small sample of the suspicious spot on your skin is taken and sent to a lab to be examined under a microscope. This will help us determine if it is cancerous or not. The procedure is usually done under local anesthesia, so you won't feel any pain. It typically involves removing a small piece of the spot or, in some cases, the entire spot. Afterward, the area will be bandaged, and you'll receive instructions on how to care for it. The results typically take a week or two to come back. Given the concerning symptoms, the biopsy is the best way to get a definitive diagnosis. Based on the information, the highest likelihood is skin cancer, particularly melanoma. "}
